title: Do you automatically get an associate’s degree after 2 years? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a question I’ve answered many times. For example, somebody will be attending a four-year college or university and think that after 2 years of being there, they now have an Associates degree. So if they were to drop out in year 3 or 4, they can say they have an Associate’s degree. You don’t have one! So just because you completed your first two years doesn’t automatically give you a degree! However, if you had enrolled in an Associates degree program and completed everything, then yes, you would officially earn the degree. And then could continue on for the Bachelors. So in order to earn an Associates, you need to be formally enrolled in that degree program. And successfully complete all the degree’s requirements. A process that could take longer than 2 years because you may be going to school part-time instead of full-time. So how long it will take you to complete all the credits you need is dependent upon your individual schedule. With a lot more working students, some are just taking one class at a time. So the 2 years is when you’re taking full loads each quarter, semester, or session. Not everybody takes a full load.

NOPE. As with any degree program (associate, bachelors, masters, doctoral) there are required course work and GPA requirements. Many (not all) masters and higher require research in the form of writing a dissertation and the like. Just going to college for a couple of years won’t give you an associate degree. Keep in mind that the “two years” applies if you are going full time, not part time. Associate degrees are usually only granted by junior/community colleges. If you go to a state university, they most likely don’t do associate degrees. So if you want an associate degree you need to:1) go to a college that offers them2) sign up for the particular program (you want an AA or an AS and in what field)3) complete the required coursework AND maintain the minimum GPA4) once you have the coursework, you’ll need to apply for the degree.

No. Time has nothing to do with getting a degree. Every degree program, including those that grant associates’ degrees, has graduation requirements. Typically, those requirements include core classes within a field or specialty, general education requirements such as composition and math, and perhaps a small number of electives. If you are a full-time student and take approximately 15 credits per semester, you can typically complete graduation requirements for an associate's degree in two years. If you switch programs, fail classes or do not achieve a passing grade, or take less than 15 credit hours per semester, it will take you longer than two years.

No. You get an associate’s degree after you complete the course requirements for that degree. If you’re majoring in underwater basketweaving and take two years worth of computer courses, you’re not going to have an associate’s degree in underwater basketweaving. You’re probably not going to have an associate’s degree in computers, either.

No. In the U.S., you do not automatically receive an associate degree at the end of two years in college. In the U.S., associate degrees are offered by two-year colleges and a few four-year colleges. To earn the degree you must enroll in a program of study, take and pass all the required courses in it, earn 60+ credits, have a grade point average sufficient to graduate (often at least 2.5 on a 4.0 scale), and apply to graduate and receive the degree.

No. An Associate's degree has specific requirements concerning courses which must be met for the degree to be awarded. Many 4 year colleges do not award Assiciate's degrees at all. To get one, a student would have to transfer to a school that awards the degree, the credits would have to be accepted by the nee school, and all required prerequisites would have to be met. The school might require certain courses. taught by them. Or it might require a certain number of their courses be taken. It might not accept some of the courses taken at the 4 year school, due to either content or grade.

No. You must meet certain requirements to obtain the degree. As in a more advanced degree, there are certain classes you MUST succeed at or you will not meet the degree requirements and hence, you get no degree.
No. Depends on what your going to school for, the cirrulculm chart should tell you what needs to be taken
Nope. You must get the correct amount of accredited courses passed and any and all graduate requirements fulfilled first.
No, you have to have passed classes that meet the schools criteria for various catagories that account for 60+ units.
No you don’t. You are required to take courses in Social Sciences, Life Sciences, Humanities, History, and English classes in addition to your elective courses.
